feedback.Physical object: Excluded — The tenure system is a policy structure, not a tangible object.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Excluded — It is institutional, not materially fabricated.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — It is not derived from biological models.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — Policies can evolve; tenure standards shift over time.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — It is not a material or physical structure.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — Its effects are visible, but the system itself is conceptual.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — It has no material embodiment.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — It functions through rules and decisions, not passive presence.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Designed to ensure academic freedom and employment stability.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — It influences outcomes indirectly via roles and protections.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — It is not a signal system.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — It does not autonomously transform.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — It is not an interface or agent.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Included — Embedded within academic governance and institutional policy frameworks.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — Relies on governance and enforcement to operate.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Important but not universally essential to the operation of an institution.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Tenure symbolizes institutional trust and professional status.
feedback.Communicative: Excluded — It is not inherently communicative, though it conveys status indirectly.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Excluded — While implemented via rules, this trait reflects internal logic processing.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Excluded — It is not internally modularized as a concept.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Included — Strongly shapes academic behaviors and career choices.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Included — The system reflects upon its own governance mechanisms.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — Though time-bound in process (e.g., probationary periods), it is not intrinsically temporal.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — The system only exists within institutional and sociocultural context.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — Defined and maintained through academic culture.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Institutions formally define its rules.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Included — It grants the role/status of 'tenured faculty'.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Included — Governed by policy documents, bylaws, and committees.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — Explained and handed down through policy, mentorship, and onboarding.
feedback.Visible: Included — Publicly recognized through announcements and directories.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Varies dramatically by institution, discipline, and country.
feedback.Widely known: Included — Recognized across the academic world and often beyond.

encoding_notes: The tenure system is modeled as a deeply social and abstract construct with strong behavioral and identity-signaling functions. Though not a communicative or logical processor itself, it operates symbolically, structurally, and within complex institutional systems. The corrected code '00848DFF' now faithfully reflects the selected traits.
